clusters.title: "Break bail, face jail": Battin vows to take tough stance on crime
clusters.neutral_headline: Victoria Opposition Leader Vows Tough Stance on Crime
bullet_summary: Leader of the Victoria Liberal Party Brad Battin has said Jacinta Allan's bail overhauls have not worked, and said more needs to be done to cut the rate of crime in the state

items.title: "Break bail, face jail": Battin vows to take tough stance on crime
items.standfirst: K nife crime continues to be a problem in Victoria.
items.content: Victoria's opposition leader Brad Battin claims he will not give judges the option to bail certain offenders as part of his pledge to crack down on crime.Despite Jacinta Allan's Labor government tightening bail laws and introducing a ban on machetes, knife crime is continuing in Victoria, with the latest incident seeing a teenager stabbed at a rugby event in Broadmeadows on Saturday.Crime is set to be a key issue in next year's state election, and speaking to Today, Battin claimed he would take a hard line where he believes Labor has been soft.READ MORE: Man dead after stabbing in popular nightlife spot"The government weakened these laws and won't return them to the position they were in 2023," he said. "Since then, that's when we've seen the crime increase.""It is getting to a stage that this is the only topic people are talking about. And that's a huge concern because then the perception becomes reality and people feel unsafe in their own community.""We've had 25 to 30 victims under the age of 25 who have died in the knife crisis here in Victoria, and they [the government] continue to have their head in the sand and won't answer the real questions of fixing the bail system, bringing in something like break bail, face jail and ensuring we have violent offenders off the street."Battin said if the Liberals were returned to government, he would put laws in place that bar courts from granting bail to some offenders."One of the key points is 'break bail, face jail'. Those that are committing violent offences shouldn't continue to get bail," he said.READ MORE: Search resumes for missing 26-year-old fisherman"We'll ensure we'll tighten the laws to make sure that the judges don't have the choice to give them bail, that they have to keep them on remand rather than back out into the community."Battin's comments come as senior police in Victoria call for greater government support.Victoria Police Commander Wayne Cheeseman claimed the department was having to draft in police officers from regional areas of the state to police protests in Melbourne CBD.One such protest last week left two police officers in hospital.Battin said he would also increase funding to the state's police, claiming the overstretched department was equipped enough to deal with crime in Victoria.READ MORE: Louvre jewellery heist investigators make a stunning claim"Mike Bush [Victoria's chief police commissioner] has got over 1100 vacancies on the roster," Battin claimed."He can't just invent police, he needs funding to ensure they get there."Battin said until the issue is fixed, a growing number of Victorians will not feel safe in their own home."It is getting to a stage that this is the only topic people are talking about," he said."And that's a huge concern because then the perception becomes reality and people feel unsafe in their own community."DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: Leader of the Victoria Liberal Party Brad Battin has said Jacinta Allan's bail overhauls have not worked, and said more needs to be done to cut the rate of crime in the state.

clusters.title: Trump threatens to hike Canadian tariffs by 10 per cent in extraordinary rant
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Threatens Tariffs on Canadian Goods
bullet_summary: The US president said he plans to hike tariffs on imports of Canadian goods by an extra 10 per cent because of an anti-tariff television ad aired by the province of Ontario

items.title: Trump threatens to hike Canadian tariffs by 10 per cent in extraordinary rant
items.standfirst: The US president said he plans to hike tariffs on imports of Canadian goods by an extra 10 per cent because of an anti-tariff television ad aired by the province of Ontario.
items.content: President Donald Trump said he plans to hike tariffs on imports of Canadian goods by an extra 10 per cent because of an anti-tariff television ad aired by the province of Ontario.The ad used the words of former President Ronald Reagan to criticise US tariffs, angering Trump who said he would end trade talks with Canada.Ontario Premier Doug Ford said he would pull the ad after the weekend, and it ran Friday night during the first game of the World Series.READ MORE: Principal's warning to parents over dangers of AI chatbot relationships “Their Advertisement was to be taken down, IMMEDIATELY, but they let it run last night during the World Series, knowing that it was a FRAUD,” Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform as he flew aboard Air Force One to Malaysia."Because of their serious misrepresentation of the facts, and hostile act, I am increasing the Tariff on Canada by 10 per cent over and above what they are paying now.”It was unclear what legal authority Trump would use to impose the additional import taxes.The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on when the 10 per cent hike would come into effect, and whether it would apply to all Canadian goods.Canada's economy has been hit hard by Trump's tariffs, and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has been trying to work with Trump to lower them.More than three-quarters of Canadian exports go to the U.S., and nearly $3.6 billion Canadian ($3.9 billion AUD) worth of goods and services cross the border daily.READ MORE: Kamala Harris hints at another presidential run: 'I am not done' A spokesperson for Carney didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.Many Canadian products have been hit with a 35 per cent tariff, while steel and aluminium face rates of 50 per cent.Energy products have a lower rate of 10 per cent, while the vast majority of goods are covered by the U.S.-Canada-Mexico Agreement, and are exempt from tariffs.That trade agreement is slated for review. Trump negotiated the deal in his first term, but has since soured on it.Trump and Carney will both attend the Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit in Malaysia. But Trump told reporters traveling with him that he had no intention of meeting Carney there.Trump said the ad misrepresented the position of Reagan, a two-term president and a beloved figure in the Republican Party. But Reagan was wary of tariffs and used much of the 1987 address featured in Ontario's ad spelling out the case against tariffs.Trump has complained the ad was aimed at influencing the U.S. Supreme Court ahead of arguments scheduled for next month that could decide whether Trump has the power to impose his sweeping tariffs, a key part of his economic strategy.Lower courts had ruled he had exceeded his authority.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: US President Donald Trump says he plans to hike tariffs on imports of Canadian goods by an extra 10 per cent because of an anti-tariff television ad aired by the province of Ontario.

ai_summary: Donald Trump plans to hike tariffs on Canadian imports by 10 percent.
The increase is due to an anti-tariff television ad.
The ad was aired by the province of Ontario.

clusters.title: Aussie women's cricketers allegedly 'touched inappropriately' on tour in India
clusters.neutral_headline: Australian Cricketers Allegedly Touched Inappropriately in India

items.title: Aussie women's cricketers allegedly 'touched inappropriately' on tour in India
items.standfirst: Female players, who are in Indore for the ICC Women's World Cup, were on their way to a café when they were allegedly "approached and touched inappropriately" by a man on a motorbike.
items.content: Two players from the Australian women's cricket team have allegedly been followed and harassed by a man in the Indian city of Indore.The female players, who are in Indore for the ICC Women's World Cup, were on their way to a café when they were allegedly "approached and touched inappropriately" by a man on a motorbike, Cricket Australia confirmed in a statement."The matter was reported by team security to police who are handling the matter," a Cricket Australia spokesperson said.READ MORE: Woman seriously injured after car ploughs into outdoor dining at Sydney cafe CCTV circulating on Indian media outlets shows a man on a moped who may be connected to the incident.A man has been arrested and is facing charges including stalking, according to The Time of India.It's understood Indian authorities have assured the team of their safety for the remainder of the tour. Currently the world's number one team, the Aussie women are preparing to take on South Africa tonight at Indore's Holkar stadium.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
